awd_titl_txt: Ultra-Low Emittance Electron Beams from Laser-Plasma Photo-Cathodes
awd_abstract_narration:
The progress of basic research into physics, biomedicine, materials science, and chemistry depends critically on the qualities of high-energy electrons. An important current application of electrons is x-ray radiology, used for medical diagnostics, homeland security, non-destructive analysis, and computer manufacturing. By developing novel methods to accelerate electrons with laser light, this project aims to demonstrate new techniques to greatly improve the quality of electron beams. In the process, a new generation of students in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics will receive training in disciplines deemed essential for national scientific and economic competitiveness. 

The development of compact high-field-gradient laser-plasma accelerators has advanced rapidly in recent years. Several recent theoretical studies predict the possibility of ultra-low emittance beams (substantially lower than the current state of the art). However, these predictions have yet to be tested experimentally. Such experiments will be conducted during this project with the cutting-edge laser technology, including the petawatt peak-power-level DIOCLES laser, available at the University of Nebraska's Extreme Light laboratory. Laser light will be used to both inject and accelerate electrons, producing beams with record low emittance. Novel methods will be developed and implemented to measure ultra-low beam emittance. The experimental results will be compared with predictions of modeling and simulation?to either validate existing physical models, or develop new ones that agree with observations. It is anticipated that this research will significantly improve our understanding of the fundamental physics of laser-wakefield electron accelerators, as well as further advance their development.

por.por_cntn:
High-quality electron beams are essential for several critical enabling technologies, including synchrotron x-ray light sources, free-electron lasers, future high-energy colliders, and for the determination of the structure and ultrafast dynamics of atomic, molecular or material systems through diffraction. The first stage of an electron accelerator, the photocathode, in which electrons are created and pre-accelerated, largely determines the ultimate quality of the accelerated electron beam. The most essential attributes are the electron beam’s charge and emittance, limited by the effects of space charge. Laser-plasma accelerators—by accelerating electrons to relativistic velocity thousand times faster than conventional RF-accelerators—have the potential to overcome the usual deleterious effects of space charge. Laser-plasma accelerators have advanced rapidly in recent years. The ultimate goal of this project was to develop significantly improved optically-driven ultra-compact electron accelerators.

We approached this by pioneering a novel way to inject free plasma electrons into accelerating wake via colliding of two laser-driven plasma wakes. We launched two laser pulses of extremely high intensity inside a plasma. The pulses pushed plasma electrons out of their ways, driving electron density wakes behind them. By controlling the delay between the pulses, we observed three types of collisions: pulse-pulse, pulse-wake, and wake-wake. In all the cases, plasma electrons got heated to relativistic energies, reaching speeds that allowed them to follow the wakes and get trapped into them. The trapped electrons were then accelerated by the wakes into high-quality and ultra-short electron bunches. By operating at record-high laser intensity, we accessed a previously unexplored regime of laser-plasma interaction (pulse-wake and wake-wake collisions). We demonstrated that in this regime, electron trapping can be precisely controlled – plasma electrons can be placed in an optimal phase of the accelerating wake by either light pressure of the laser pulse (pulse-wake collision) or another wake (wake-wake collision).

We also developed a novel technique of measuring emittance of ultra-short, ultra-small electron beams in a non-destructive and single-shot mode. It relies on an intense laser pulse, which is used to probe the electron beam, and spectroscopic imaging of the generated inverse-Compton scattered x-rays, as well as its knife-edge imaging. Angular-resolved spectrum of the x-rays carries signatures of the electron beam, which allows deducing electron beam energy, energy spread, and divergence. Knife-edge imaging of the x-rays allows deducing the electron-beam source size. These parameters together constitute electron beam transverse emittance.
